title: This Place: Heaven on earth, where the Biliar people go to speak with their creator and ancestors Phillip Ugle is a proud Wilman Noongar man who has fought for decades to ensure the sustainability of his people's culture.Duration: 1 minute 51 seconds1m 51s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Djimubarn, sacred rock art shelterIn Western Arnhem Land the Markani estate of the Madjawarr clan is full of stories.Duration: 4 minutes 19 seconds4m 19s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Walking in the footsteps of the Ancestors at Turikina TruwalaTheresa Sainty is a Pakana woman with a strong connection to Kunyani/Mt Wellington. Here she talks about Turikina Truwala at the foothills of the mountain and explains what this palawa kani word is translated to and what this place means to her.Duration: 2 minutes 48 seconds2m 48s
subject: Languages

title: Eat the Invaders: The taste testTony Armstrong interviews children in Winchelsea, Victoria, about their thoughts on eating rabbit, and he keeps them company while they taste rabbit for the first time!Duration: 2 minutes 27 seconds2m 27s
subject: Languages

title: Eat the Invaders: DeerTony Armstrong is in Tasmania where he speaks to Professor Chris Johnson from the University of Tasmania about the complexity of managing wild deer populations in Australia.Duration: 2 minutes 14 seconds2m 14s
subject: Languages

title: Yarrabil Bula: First Nations SongsSing along with First Nations people as they share more songs using language from their Country. Learn words in the Yugambeh, Yawuru, Wiradjuri, Pitjantjatjara, palawa kani and Arrernte languages.
subject: Languages

title: Behind Yarrabil Bula: More First Nations SongsMeet the performers behind Yarrabil Bula: First Nations Songs. Learn about the value of using song to help revitalise language for all generations.Duration: 12 minutes 3 seconds12m
subject: Languages

title: Yarrabil Bula: The Greeting SongHello friends! How are you? Sing along and learn how to greet your friends in First Nations languages, including Yugambeh, Yawuru, Wiradjuri, Pitjantjatjara, palawa kani, Miriam Mer and Arrernte.Duration: 4 minutes 31 seconds4m 31s
subject: Languages

title: Yarrabil Bula: Jubi in the JangeegeriJubi in the Jangeegeri (“A mud crab in the mangroves”) is a song written by Faith Baisden and performed by Alinta McGrady. This song incorporates animal names in the Yugambeh language.Duration: 3 minutes 21 seconds3m 21s
subject: Languages

title: Wiradjuri Shake-a-Leg Hokey PokeyWiradjuri Shake-a-Leg Hokey Pokey is a song written and performed by Sharron mirii Bell. The song incorporates words in the Wiradjuri language.Duration: 3 minutes 38 seconds3m 38s
subject: Languages

title: Liyan NurluLiyan Nurlu ("Feelings song") is a song written by the Cable Beach Primary School's Yawuru Language Team, and performed by Bart Pigram and Maarli Pigram. The song is sung entirely in the Yawuru language.Duration: 2 minutes 32 seconds2m 32s
subject: Languages

title: Counting Song in palawa kani Counting Song in palawa kani is a song written by Faith Baisden, translated by Theresa Sainty and performed by Merinda Sainty. This song is performed entirely in palawa kani language.Duration: 2 minutes 3 seconds2m 3s
subject: Languages

title: Maṟa Kuḻunypa KutjuMara Kulunypa Kutju ("Five little fingers") is a song performed by Dominic Ngalatji Barry and Tjutjuna Paul Andy. The song is sung entirely in the Pitjantjatjara language.Duration: 3 minutes 8 seconds3m 8s
subject: Languages

title: Iwenhe Ingwele ArratemeIwenhe Ingwele Arrateme ("What comes out at night") is a song written by Children's Ground and performed by Myles Turner. This song is performed entirely in Arrernte language.Duration: 2 minutes 44 seconds2m 44s
subject: Languages

title: Yarrabil: First Nations SongsSing along with First Nations people as they share songs using language from their Country. Learn words in the Gooreng Gooreng, Noongar, Dharug, Meriam Mir, Gunditjmara and Kaurna languages.
subject: Languages

title: Behind Yarrabil: First Nations SongsMeet the performers behind Yarrabil: First Nations Songs. Learn about the value of using song to help revitalise language, and hear the stories behind some of the songs.Duration: 4 minutes 29 seconds4m 29s
subject: Languages

title: Ngany Noongar BoodjaNgany Noongar Boodja ("My Noongar Country") is a song written and performed by Jillian Moody. The song incorporates words in the Noongar language.Duration: 3 minutes 20 seconds3m 20s
subject: Languages

title: Vullah Vunnah NahVullah Vunnah Nah ("He sends the rainbow") is a song written by Patricia Clarke and performed by Brett Clarke. The song is sung in both English and the Gunditjmara language.Duration: 3 minutes 2 seconds3m 2s

title: Kerkeri WedKerkeri Wed ("Sand crab song") is a song written and performed by Ruth Ghee. The song is sung in both English and Meriam Mir, which is a language spoken in the eastern Torres Strait Islands.Duration: 2 minutes 13 seconds2m 13s

title: Budyari Nhaady'unyila NgurrawaBudyari Nhaady'unyila Ngurrawa ("Good to see you all on Country") is a song written by Jasmine Seymour. The song is sung entirely in the Dharug language by Jasmine Seymour and Corina Norman.Duration: 2 minutes 33 seconds2m 33s
subject: Languages

title: Niina MarniNiina Marni ("Are you good?") is a greeting song written by Aunty Cherie Watkins and performed by Alison Denee. The song is sung entirely in the Kaurna language.Duration: 2 minutes 10 seconds2m 10s
subject: Languages

title: No Buru on the BusNo Buru on the Bus ("No kangaroos on the bus") is a song written by Faith Baisden and performed by Robert dhurwain McLellan. This song incorporates animal names in the Gooreng Gooreng language.Duration: 3 minutes 23 seconds3m 23s

title: This PlaceA digibook to complement the series.  Across Australia, places are known for their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander names. But what do they mean? Indigenous communities share the stories behind place names of their country.
subject: Languages

title: This Place: GununaJohnny Williams and Karen Chong are traditional owners from Gununa, Mornington Island. The community on the island respect the land and its history and in turn the land and sea provide for them.Duration: 4 minutes 20 seconds4m 20s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Marrambidya BilaMark Saddler of Wiradjuri Country speaks of traditional walkways and how the Murrumbidgee River is central to Wagga Wagga.Duration: 2 minutes 48 seconds2m 48s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Leanganook — His TeethHigh above the ground stands Leanganook or Mount Alexander which means 'his teeth'.Duration: 2 minutes 40 seconds2m 40s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Little Wave RockLittle Wave Rock is a gathering place that harbours the history and many secrets of Gamilaraay ancestors.Duration: 2 minutes 46 seconds2m 46s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: The Significance of the Waterways to Wangal PeopleWangal people know Sydney as the place of eel Dreaming.Duration: 2 minutes 38 seconds2m 38s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Binalup, Morning LightAmong the many significant places in Albany, on Western Australia's south coast, lies Binalup.Duration: 3 minutes 5 seconds3m 5s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Hunting for Goannas in the Western DesertLeah Robinson and her Martu families love to hunt sand goannas in the western desert region of WA.Duration: 2 minutes 37 seconds2m 37s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: GoguljarGoguljar is the traditional name for the Avon River. Traditional owner and Baladang Nyungar land holder Oral McGuire is working to regenerate land and has discovered ceremonial sites of cultural significance to the Baladong Nyungar people.Duration: 4 minutes 4 seconds4m 4s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Wiradjuri — Why we see Shooting StarsWhen Wiradjuri woman Jody Chester looks up at the Milky Way, she sees the stars of her ancestors.Duration: 1 minute 57 seconds1m 57s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: BobbinawarraBobbinawarra is Bangerang for pelican, and you are almost guaranteed to see one in the lakes, ponds and rivers that surround this tiny locale.Duration: 3 minutes 1 second3m 1s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: GujiragunUnder the world's oldest picture garden in Broome, WA, sits a jila, or waterhole. Yawuru man Jimmy Edgar remembers the Dream time stories of this important meeting place for people from many cultures over thousands of years.Duration: 2 minutes 32 seconds2m 32s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Looking out from Kaart Gennunginyup BoResearching the culture and language of place names of the Whadjuk Nyungar people has been a lifelong pursuit for Professor Len Collard.Duration: 2 minutes 45 seconds2m 45s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: How Looern and the Swan Sisters Gave Us GraniteThe Wathaurung people of Victoria share a fascinating creation story with their neighbouring tribal groupsDuration: 4 minutes 35 seconds4m 35s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Nari Nari Burial GroundsJamie Woods of Nari Nari Tribal council reveals the long social and personal journey leading to the repatriation of hundreds of burial sites across the plains west of Hay in NSW.Duration: 3 minutes 43 seconds3m 43s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Gummingurru — Men of the RiverTraditional custodian Shannon Bauwens takes us to Gummingurru, a place name chosen by the Elders when their land was returned to them.Duration: 2 minutes 12 seconds2m 12s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Making ochre at luyni mungalinaluyni mungalina is a waterfall in Launceston, Tasmania. Indigenous language teacher Rosetta Thomas shares the story behind the falls and explains the special role they play in traditional dance and ceremonies.Duration: 3 minutes 5 seconds3m 5s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: The Woggaal Maadjit's EggsThe thrombolites in Lake Clifton in WA are thought to be one of the first life forms on Earth.Duration: 3 minutes 59 seconds3m 59s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: The Goanna Spirit on Anderson Sugarloaf MountainThe Dhanggati name for Anderson Sugarloaf Mountain is Barralbarayi. It was a place where the men would take the boys for initiation.Duration: 3 minutes 39 seconds3m 39s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: A Healing Place at the WaterClarence Wyles Jnr is a Ranger and a proud Warrgamay man. He shares his knowledge of the healing place (Broadwater) where his old people made camp and washed away negativity by swimming in the water.Duration: 2 minutes 49 seconds2m 49s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: The Journey of the Bogong MothsMungabareena means a "special meeting place" in Wiradjuri language. People would meet there on their way to Mt Bogong to collect Bogong moths and return to Mungabareena to feast on them.Duration: 2 minutes 41 seconds2m 41s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: How the Black Swan Gave Maroochydore its NameKabi Kabi man Kerry Neill shares the Aboriginal Dreaming story behind popular tourist destinations on the Sunshine Coast in Queensland.Duration: 3 minutes 25 seconds3m 25s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Boat RockThe land surrounding Berrigan is flat as far as the eye can see — except for one rocky out crop hidden down a dirt road and surrounded by farmland.Duration: 2 minutes 49 seconds2m 49s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Mugincoble — An Ancient Gathering PlaceMugincoble is a sacred meeting place for the Wiradjuri nation but is now private property.Duration: 3 minutes 43 seconds3m 43s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Bung Yarnda — Camping WatersBung Yarnda (Lake Tyers) has a rich history as being a fishing, feasting and camping place for Gunai clans in east Victoria.Duration: 3 minutes 48 seconds3m 48s
subject: Languages

title: This Place: Language on CountryWarrgamay place names provide a wealth of history and knowledge of Country.Duration: 4 minutes 26 seconds4m 26s
